articles.headline: Changing Its Tune
articles.snippet: Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making as broadcast radio scrambles to regain its groove.
articles.abstract: Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making as broadcast radio scrambles to regain its groove.
articles.lead_paragraph: The radio industry keeps losing people like Danny C. Costa, a senior at Boston University who grew up listening to radio in New York and New Jersey.

articles.headline: Uganda Peace Hinges on Amnesty for Brutality
articles.snippet: Whether a cease-fire in Uganda’s Acholi war lasts may depend on whether a rebel commander is given amnesty.
articles.abstract: Whether a cease-fire in Uganda’s Acholi war lasts may depend on whether a rebel commander is given amnesty.
articles.lead_paragraph: GULU, Uganda — In the beginning, it was simply called the Acholi war, and despite its brutality, few people outside Uganda paid attention.

articles.headline: Ford Offering 75,000 Employees Buyout Packages
articles.snippet: The U.A.W. agreed on a program to offer buyouts of up to $140,000 each to all of Ford’s hourly workers in the U.S.
articles.abstract: The U.A.W. agreed on a program to offer buyouts of up to $140,000 each to all of Ford’s hourly workers in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 14 — The Ford Motor Company agreed Thursday to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: California, Taking Big Gamble, Tries to Curb Greenhouse Gases
articles.snippet: California is betting that it can reduce emissions without wrecking its economy, and inspire other states to follow its example.
articles.abstract: California is betting that it can reduce emissions without wrecking its economy, and inspire other states to follow its example.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In the Rocky Mountain States and the fast-growing desert Southwest, more than 20 power plants, designed to burn coal that is plentiful and cheap, are on the drawing boards. Much of the power, their owners expected, would be destined for the people of California.

articles.headline: Losing Money by Buying Stock Back
articles.snippet: The buy high-sell low strategy may be a recipe for disaster for your average investor. But for companies, it has been a way to improve reported profits.
articles.abstract: The buy high-sell low strategy may be a recipe for disaster for your average investor. But for companies, it has been a way to improve reported profits.

articles.headline: Murdoch Said to Be in Talks With Liberty on Stock Swap
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch is said to be in talks with the financer John C. Malone to trade his stake in the DirecTV Group.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch is said to be in talks with the financer John C. Malone to trade his stake in the DirecTV Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, who spent nearly two decades coveting an American satellite broadcaster before acquiring control of the DirecTV Group three years ago, is now in talks to trade his stake to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Document Could Alter KPMG Case
articles.snippet: An I.R.S. document indicates that KPMG did not have to register questionable tax shelters, undermining a major claim in the case against 18 former tax professionals.
articles.abstract: An I.R.S. document indicates that KPMG did not have to register questionable tax shelters, undermining a major claim in the case against 18 former tax professionals.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that the accounting firm KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government’s case against 18 former tax professionals.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Flirt With Heresy: Going Public
articles.snippet: The hedge fund Fortress Investment Group is said to be considering an initial public offering that could value the company from $5 billion to $7 billion.
articles.abstract: The hedge fund Fortress Investment Group is said to be considering an initial public offering that could value the company from $5 billion to $7 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge funds — fast-growing private investment pools of capital — are known for their secrecy.

articles.headline: Murdoch Said to Be in Talks With Liberty on Stock Swap
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch, who spent nearly two decades coveting an American satellite broadcaster before acquiring control of the DirecTV Group three years ago, is now in talks to trade his stake to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks sai...
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch, who spent nearly two decades coveting an American satellite broadcaster before acquiring control of the DirecTV Group three years ago, is now in talks to trade his stake to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night.     In return, the News Corporation, controlled by Mr. Murdoch, would get Mr. Malone's 19 percent stake in News Corporation, these people said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, who spent nearly two decades coveting an American satellite broadcaster before acquiring control of the DirecTV Group three years ago, is now in talks to trade his stake to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Ford Offering 75,000 Employees Buyout Packages
articles.snippet: The Ford Motor Company agreed Thursday to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs.     The deal with the United Automobile Workers com...
articles.abstract: The Ford Motor Company agreed Thursday to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs.     The deal with the United Automobile Workers comes after a similar offer at General Motors earlier this year that was accepted by nearly a third of its union workers. It is also the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 14 - The Ford Motor Company agreed Thursday to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Uganda Peace Hinges on Amnesty for Brutality
articles.snippet: In the beginning, it was simply called the Acholi war, and despite its brutality, few people outside Uganda paid attention.     The Lord's Resistance Army, a messianic rebel group, was exploring a new dimension of violence by building an army of a...
articles.abstract: In the beginning, it was simply called the Acholi war, and despite its brutality, few people outside Uganda paid attention.     The Lord's Resistance Army, a messianic rebel group, was exploring a new dimension of violence by building an army of abducted children and forcing them to burn down huts, slice off lips and pound newborn babies to death in wooden mortars, as though they were grinding grain.
articles.lead_paragraph: GULU, Uganda - In the beginning, it was simply called the Acholi war, and despite its brutality, few people outside Uganda paid attention.

articles.headline: Losing Money by Buying Stock Back
articles.snippet: BUY high. Sell low.     For your average investor, that is a recipe for disaster. But for companies, it has actually been a way to improve reported profits even as the cash flows out the door.
articles.abstract: BUY high. Sell low.     For your average investor, that is a recipe for disaster. But for companies, it has actually been a way to improve reported profits even as the cash flows out the door.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Flirt With Heresy: Going Public
articles.snippet: Hedge funds -- fast-growing private investment pools of capital -- are known for their secrecy.      That is partly because federal regulations prohibit them from advertising or talking to anyone but their investors. But being private and secretiv...
articles.abstract: Hedge funds -- fast-growing private investment pools of capital -- are known for their secrecy.      That is partly because federal regulations prohibit them from advertising or talking to anyone but their investors. But being private and secretive also enables them to develop investment strategies and manage their business, big fees included, without the Corporate Library criticizing their outsize pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge funds -- fast-growing private investment pools of capital -- are known for their secrecy.

articles.headline: California, Taking Big Gamble, Tries to Curb Greenhouse Gases
articles.snippet: In the Rocky Mountain States and the fast-growing desert Southwest, more than 20 power plants, designed to burn coal that is plentiful and cheap, are on the drawing boards. Much of the power, their owners expected, would be destined for the people...
articles.abstract: In the Rocky Mountain States and the fast-growing desert Southwest, more than 20 power plants, designed to burn coal that is plentiful and cheap, are on the drawing boards. Much of the power, their owners expected, would be destined for the people of California.     But such plants would also be among the country's most potent producers of carbon dioxide, the king of gases linked to global warming. So California has just delivered a new message to these energy suppliers: If you cannot produce power with the lowest possible emissions of these greenhouse gases, we are not interested.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO - In the Rocky Mountain States and the fast-growing desert Southwest, more than 20 power plants, designed to burn coal that is plentiful and cheap, are on the drawing boards. Much of the power, their owners expected, would be destined for the people of California.

articles.headline: Document Could Alter KPMG Case
articles.snippet: A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that the accounting firm KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals.   ...
articles.abstract: A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that the accounting firm KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals.      The emergence of the document is the latest setback to what federal prosecutors have called the largest criminal case ever against the makers and sellers of questionable tax shelters.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that the accounting firm KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals.

articles.headline: REBUFF FOR BUSH ON HOW TO TREAT TERROR SUSPECTS
articles.snippet: The Senate Armed Services Committee defied President Bush on Thursday, with four Republicans joining Democrats in approving a plan for the trial and interrogation of terrorism suspects that the White House has rejected as unacceptable.     The Rep...
articles.abstract: The Senate Armed Services Committee defied President Bush on Thursday, with four Republicans joining Democrats in approving a plan for the trial and interrogation of terrorism suspects that the White House has rejected as unacceptable.     The Republican rebellion was led by Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the committee chairman, with backing from Senators John McCain of Arizona, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Susan Collins of Maine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The Senate Armed Services Committee defied President Bush on Thursday, with four Republicans joining Democrats in approving a plan for the trial and interrogation of terrorism suspects that the White House has rejected as unacceptable.

articles.headline: Changing Its Tune
articles.snippet: The radio industry keeps losing people like Danny C. Costa, a senior at Boston University who grew up listening to radio in New York and New Jersey.     For the last few years, Mr. Costa has tuned out radio in favor of Web sites where he can get a...
articles.abstract: The radio industry keeps losing people like Danny C. Costa, a senior at Boston University who grew up listening to radio in New York and New Jersey.     For the last few years, Mr. Costa has tuned out radio in favor of Web sites where he can get access to downloads or videos he heard about from friends. He prefers these to the drumbeat of the Top 40. He burns his favorite songs onto CD's or copies them onto his iPod.
articles.lead_paragraph: The radio industry keeps losing people like Danny C. Costa, a senior at Boston University who grew up listening to radio in New York and New Jersey.
